title-group.article-title: The invasion of Cassytha filiformis accelerated the litter decomposition of native plant communities in small tropical coral islands

sec.title: Background
sec.p: Plant invasion affects plant community composition, biodiversity, and nutrient cycling in terrestrial ecosystems, particularly in vulnerable ecosystems. As an invasive parasitic plant, Cassytha filiformis has caused extensive damage to the native vegetation of the Paracel Islands. However, the effects of C. filiformis invasion on litter decomposition and nutrient release in native plant communities remain unclear. We conducted an in-situ decomposition experiment in native plant communities on a coral island to explore the litter decomposition dynamics varying across enzyme activities, soil properties and C. filiformis invasive degrees.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The mass loss of litter was determined during the decomposition process. The data showed that litter mass loss under severe invasion was significantly lower than in uninvaded sites after nine months of decomposition. The invasion of C. filiformis accelerated the nitrogen release and lignin decomposition with increased litter quality and polyphenol oxidase activity. Besides, soil phosphorus availability and potassium content also induced the oxidase activity. Meanwhile, the decomposition of litter organic carbon was delayed because β-1, 4-glucosidase activity was low in the first six months. Besides, peroxidase activity maintained a high level in invasive plots, indicating that the residues of C. filiformis may have allelopathy.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Our results suggested that the invasion of C. filiformis accelerated litter mass loss and element release on coral islands by regulating litter quality and enzyme activity. However, the short-term rapid litter decomposition may result in nutrient loss, which is not conducive to the growth of native plants.

sec.title: Supplementary Information
sec.p: The online version contains supplementary material available at 10.1186/s12870-025-06556-0.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Plant litter decomposition is a key ecological process in the biosphere, which has important effects on carbon cycling, nutrient release and ecosystem functions maintenance [5, 38]. Litter is not only a link between plants and soil but also an important carrier of nutrient transformation in above-ground and subsurface ecosystems [16, 23]. Exploring the factors affecting litter decomposition and their mechanisms is essential for understanding the ongoing responses of the stability and health of ecosystems to invasion in fragile coral island ecosystems.

Plant invasions are known to disrupt native ecosystems. The influence of invasive plants on litter decomposition has always been widely concerned in invaded ecosystems. Plant invasion is generally accompanied by alterations in ecosystem processes, including reduced primary productivity, altered rates of litter decomposition and trophic relationships [6, 28]. Plant invasion alters the species composition of native vegetation, which results in the changes of community structure and understory micro-habitats [7, 20]. Changes in the above-ground and below-ground environment of native communities have direct effects on the decomposition rate and nutrient release of litter from dominant tree species [34]. Litter from invasive plant species may contain more concentrations of nutrients to that of native plant species. This could have implications for decomposition rates [24], which accelerated nutrient cycling in the ecosystem. In some contexts, the mixed litter of invasive plants and native plants improved the overall litter quality and promoted litter decomposition [27], thus changing soil nutrient dynamics and plant-soil feedback [2]. However, the effects of plant invasion on nutrient cycling within plant communities via litter were multifaceted and typically modulated by an interplay of biotic and abiotic factors.

As biological catalysts, extracellular enzymes secreted by microorganisms are the “gatekeepers” of the nutrient cycle, directly involved in the decomposition of litter [18], which plays important roles in the cycling of carbon, nitrogen and phosphorus. The quality of litter directly affects the nutrient requirements and metabolic activities of soil microorganisms, and then affects the production and activity of enzymes. The addition of high-quality litter significantly improves soil enzyme activity, especially those associated with the decomposition of carbon and nitrogen, such as β− 1, 4-glucosidase (BG) and β− 1, 4-N-acetylglucosidase (NAG), which play a key role in promoting the decomposition of organic matter and the release of nutrients [17]. By contrast, low-quality litter may not provide adequate nutrients, reducing enzyme activity and slowing litter decomposition [12]. Notably, enzymes, as a link between soil nutrients and litter, can be affected by multiple abiotic and biotic factors. During litter decomposition, soil extracellular enzyme activity changes with soil nutrients and litter substrates, affecting the release of litter carbon, nitrogen and phosphorus acquisition [3]. Extracellular enzyme activity was affected by litter matrix and soil nutrient availability. For example, it was found that extracellular enzymes were significantly regulated by soil nutrients and litter substrates [36]. In some cases, soil nutrient availability was even explored as the main factor affecting the activity of extracellular enzymes [8]. The previous studies demonstrated that litter quality affects soil ecoenzymatic stoichiometry, regardless of decomposition time [11]. Despite the significant body of literature already available on this field, the relationship between litter quality, enzyme activity and soil nutrient availability in vulnerable forest ecosystems affected by exotic plant invasion isn’t fully understood.

Cassytha filiformis L. (Lauraceae) is a perennial, stem hemiparasitic vine native to China mainland and was found to erupt occasionally in a few areas, resulting in slower tree growth, fruit loss and death of young trees [7, 25]. C. filiformis were recognized on the Paracel Islands (tropical coral islands) formally in 1970 s [37]. Decades later, the hemiparasite has been found on almost all coral islands (field survey). The effects of C. filiformis invasions on above-ground vegetation and soil properties on tropical coral islands have been clarified [7]. However, the effects of C. filiformis invasion on litter nutrient release and soil nutrient transformation of native plant communities in tropical coral islands are still unclear.

Cassytha filiformis invasion inputs high-quality litter, affects enzyme activity, and changes the nutrient release of litter. Thus, we conducted a 90-d in-situ decomposition experiment in a native forest invaded by C. filiformis on the Paracel Islands. We explored whether litter quality affects soil microbial metabolism during litter decomposition. We hypothesized that (1) C. filiformis invasion improves litter quality and accelerates litter element release; (2) enzyme activities are affected by soil C content, soil N content, and invasive degrees; and (3) the mass loss rate of litter is affected by soil enzyme activity and decomposition time directly, and by C. filiformis invasion and soil properties indirectly.

sec.title: Study site
sec.p: This study was carried out on Yongxing Island (16°49ʹN- 16°50ʹN, 112°20ʹE 112°21ʹE), a coral island of the Paracel Islands in the South China Sea. The island is situated in the central tropics and experiences a characteristic tropical marine climate characterized by consistently high temperatures throughout the year. The annual mean temperature ranges from 26 to 27 °C. The island receives an annual total precipitation of 1500 mm, while the annual evaporation capacity is 2400 mm. About 353 plant species grow on the island, 187 of which are wild species [35]. The island has mainly guano phosphatic coral-sand soils, and the remaining immature soils are predominantly composed of coral sands [20]. The vegetation is characterized by the dominant native tree species Pisonia grandis and Guettarda speciosa, with a sparse shrub layer and a dense ground cover of herbs, such as Scaevola taccada, Stenotaphrum micranthum and so on. Yongxing, as the capital of Sansha City, is the island that has experienced the highest introduction of exotic plant species by humans, and it is also one of the islands seriously affected by the invasion of C. filiformis (Fig. S1).

Sampling from the same area before and after the invasion is the ideal way to determine the effect of plant invasions. This method, however, requires > 5 years of monitoring, which is not practical and is often unaffordable, especially for fragile ecosystems on small islands far from the mainland. As an alternative, forest communities that presumably had similar original plant communities were sampled, and divided them into three invasive degrees (IDegree) according to the visual coverage of C. filiformis, i.e. none (0%), mild (25–35%), and severe (over 50%) invasion [21]; we assumed that the non-invaded community represented the pre-invasion condition.

sec.title: Experimental design and sampling
sec.p:
The below-ground litter manipulation plots were established in July 2023. Before this experiment, a comprehensive investigation of plants and soils was carried out in June 2018 to ensure the comparability (such as similar topographies with mean slope < 5) of the sampling plots. Five plots were conducted randomly in each invasive degree of C. filiformis (i.e. none, mild, and severe). The dynamic changes of litter decomposition of invasive and native species in plant communities were investigated by in situ litter decomposition experiment (see Table 1). Litter from native plants and C. filiformis in the community was collected in the plots and dried in the laboratory. The litter of C. filiformis decomposes so qucikly that we can hardly collect the litter of C. filiformis on the ground. Thus, we chose the old, yellowing C. filiformis individuals to represent their litter. Three different litter combination treatments and a control treatments were set up in these plots of C. filiformis invasive degrees, every treatment had five 1 mm nylon mesh screens containing 10 g litter. In uninvaded plots, litter containing native dominant plants was mixed in equal mass. In mild invasion plots, the litter mass ratio of C. filiformis to native plants was 3:7. In severe invasion plots, the litter mass ratio of C. filiformis to native plants was 1:1. The control litterbags with no litter inputs were used used to monitor whether they got into litterbags and affected the decomposition process. During our experiment, we found nothing but tiny soil particles that fall off easily in the control litterbags. A total of 75 litterbags (including five empty litterbags per block) were randomly placed on the soil surface on November, 2020. A detailed description of six treatments was shown in Table 1. Table 1
The detailed methods of litter combination treatments
TreatmentsMethods
Control (CK)No litter input. A 0.4 mm empty horizontal nylon screen was installed 0.4 m above the ground to eliminate above-ground litter, and the litter on the screen was removed once a month in each plot
UninvadedNative plant species litter mixed, mainly containing 3 native species (i.e. P. grandis, G. speciosa, and S. taccada)
MildThe litter mass mixing ratio of C. filiformis to native plant was 3:7, and there were 3 native plant species (i.e. P. grandis, G. speciosa, and S. taccada)
SevereThe litter mass mixing ratio of C. filiformis to native plant was 1:1, and there were 3 native plant species (i.e. P. grandis, G. speciosa, and S. taccada)

sec.title: Litter collection and measurements
sec.p: The litter decomposition experiment was carried out in July 2023, with litter samples collected every three months (in October 2023, January 2024, and April 2024). The experiment lasted for nine months, and the decomposition time (DTime) was defined as the time scale from the beginning of the experiment to the sampling. One litterbag was collected in each treatment within each plot, resulting in a total of 15 bags collected in each sampling time. The litterbags were put into large envelopes and placed in ice boxes with ice packs to bring back to the laboratory for processing and measurement.

The impurities on the litter surface were removed in the laboratory, and all the litter samples were weighed to calculate the mass loss rate. Subsequently, the litter samples were ground and sifted to facilitate the analysis of litter organic carbon content (LC), litter total N content (LN), litter total P content (LP), litter lignin content (LL) and other indicators (e.g. litter organic carbon content/litter total N content ratio (C/N), litter lignin content/litter total N content ratio (L/N)) after decomposition. Litter organic carbon content was determined by oxidation with potassium dichromate in a heated oil bath, total N was determined by the indophenol blue colorimetric method, and total P was determined by molybdenum-antimony resistance colorimetric method (Liu, 1996). Lignin was determined with reference to acetyl bromide colorimetry [33].

sec.title: Soil properties
sec.p: Soil samples were collected in July 2023 and January 2024, representing the wet (first sampling) and dry (third sampling) seasons on Yongxing Island, respectively. The topsoil (0–10 cm) samples were collected using 3.5 cm diameter stainless steel cylinders after litter removal. The samples were homogenized and stored at 4℃. All soil samples were sieved through a 2-mm mesh. A small subsample was removed from each soil sample and stored at − 20℃ for soil enzyme measurement. Other samples were stored at 4℃ to analyze soil physicochemical and microbial properties. The following soil variables were measured as described by Liu (1996): pH, salinity, and contents of organic matter (C), total nitrogen (Couteaux et al.), total phosphorus (TP), available phosphorus (AP), and potassium (K).

sec.title: Soil enzyme activity
sec.p: The enzymes BG, NAG, alkaline phosphatase (ALP), and polyphenol oxidase (PPO) are associated with the transformation of litter carbon, nitrogen, phosphorus, and lignin, respectively, while peroxidase (POD) activity reflects the microbial capacity to adapt to soil environmental stress [3]. The BG, NAG, ALP, PPO, and POD levels were measured with micro-plates exoenzyme assay according to Saiya-Cork [14]. After incubating assay plates at 20℃ for 4 h, the fluorescence was measured with excitation of 365 nm and emission filters of 450 nm using a thermo multi-functional microplate reader (Thermo scientific, Finland). The enzymatic activities were expressed as nanomoles of substrate released per hour per gram of dry soil or litter (nmol g−1 h−1).

sec.title: Statistical analyses
sec.p: One-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) was used to evaluate the mass loss and enzyme activities of litter decomposition with different C. filiformis invasive degrees and decomposition periods. And Two-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) was used to evaluate the effects of C. filiformis invasion and decomposition time on element release of litter decomposition. In all cases, more than two groups were examined, and least significant difference (LSD) tests were conducted to compare the associated group means [9]. The data of enzyme activities, soil properties, C. filiformis invasive degrees, and decomposition time were variance-stabilized for the Pearson correlation and heatmap analysis. A structural equation model (SEM) was constructed to quantify the direct and indirect effects of C. filiformis invasion, decomposition time, enzyme activities, soil properties, and litter quality on mass loss of litter decomposition [26] with the piecewiseSEM package. All statistical analyses were performed in R software 4.3.2.

sec.title: Mass loss and element release of litter decomposition
sec.p:
The mass of litter significantly decreased during the decomposition experiment (Fig. 1). The litter mass had no significant difference between the three invasive degrees at the 3rd and 6 th month of the decomposition experiment, and the litter mass at the 9 th month of the decomposition experiment was lowest (Fig. S2). The LC, LL and L/N decreased with litter decomposition (Fig. 2). In uninvaded plots, LN and LP increased as the decomposition time increased, while LN and LP increased first and then decreased in mild and severe invasion plots. The litter C/N decreased with litter decomposition in uninvaded plots. The litter C/N in mild and severe invasion plots was the lowest after three months of decomposition, and increased at six months and nine months after litter decomposition.Fig. 1
The dynamics of litter decomposition in different degrees of C. filiformis invasion. Uninvaded = the native community not invaded by C. filiformis; Mild = the native community of mild invaded by C. filiformis; Severe = the native community of severe invaded by C. filiformis. * = p < 0.05; ** = p < 0.01. M0 (the yellow points): zero months after decomposition; M3 (the red points): M6 (the green points): six months after decomposition; M9 (the purple points) = nine months after decompositionFig. 2
Dynamics of litter nutrient release in different invasive degrees on Yongxing Island. Uninvaded = the native community not invaded by C. filiformis; Mild = the native community was mild invaded by C. filiformis; Severe = the native community was severe invaded by C. filiformis. LC = litter C content; LN = litter N content; LP = litter P content; C/N = LC/LN; LL = litter lignin content; L/N = LL/LN. The ns = no significant; * = p < 0.05, ** = p < 0.01, *** = p < 0.001. M0 (the blue points): zero months after decomposition; M3 (the red points): M6 (the green points): six months after decomposition; M9 (the purple points) = nine months after decomposition

sec.title: Dynamics of enzyme activity
sec.p:
The dynamics of enzyme activity changed with the decomposition time and C. filiformis invasive degrees (Fig. 3). BG activities peaked at the 6 th month of the decomposition experiment in the uninvaded plots, at the 9 th month of the decomposition experiment in mild and severe invaded plots. NAG activities peaked at 6 th month of decomposition experiment in the uninvaded and mildly invaded plots and at the 9 th month of the decomposition in severely invaded plots. ALP activities peaked at the 3rd month of the decomposition experiment uninvaded and mildly invaded plots, at the 9 th month of the decomposition in severely invaded plots. In the invaded plots, BG, NAG and ALP were all peaked at the 9 th month of the decomposition experiment. PPO and POD activities decreased with litter decomposition in all plots. At the 9 th month of the decomposition experiment, PPO activity of invaded plots was lower than that of uninvaded plots, while POD activity of invaded plots was higher than that of uninvaded plots.Fig. 3
The dynamics of five enzymes in different degrees of C. filiformis invasion on Yongxing Island. Uninvaded = the native community not invaded by C. filiformis; Mild = the native community of mild invaded by C. filiformis; Severe = the native community of severe invaded by C. filiformis. M3 = three months after decomposition; M6 = six months after decomposition; M9 = nine months after decomposition

sec.title: The correlation between enzyme and soil properties in different invasive degrees and decomposition periods
sec.p:
The enzyme activity was significantly related to litter decomposition time, invasive degrees, and soil properties (Fig. 4). BG, NAG and ALP had a positive relation with DTime, while PPO and POD had a negative relation with DTime. PPO had a negative relation with IDegree, while POD had a positive relation with IDegree. BG, NAG, PPO and POD were significantly related to AP and pH. NAG, PPO and POD were significantly related to K. POD was significantly related to N and Salinity.Fig. 4
The correlation between enzyme and soil properties in different invasive degrees and decomposition periods on Yongxing Island. DTime = decomposition time; IDegree = invasive degree

sec.title: Relationships between enzyme activities, litter decomposition and environmental factors
sec.p:
The SEM explained 88% of the variation of litter mass loss (Fig. 5). Both C. filiformis invasion and decomposition time had positive effects on the mass loss of litter directly. The decomposition time significantly affected soil properties and enzyme activity, while C. filiformis invasion significantly affected enzyme activity. However, neither soil properties nor enzyme activity affected mass loss significantly. The enzyme activity affected the element release of litter directly and affected the mass loss of litter indirectly.Fig. 5
Effects of soil properties, enzyme activities, litter decomposition and C. filiformis invasion on the litter mass on Yongxing Island on structural equation model (SEM). Numbers adjacent to arrows are standardized path coefficients, analogous to relative regression weights, and indicative of the effect size of the relationship. Continuous and dashed arrows indicate significant and non-significant relationships, respectively. Arrow width is proportional to the strength of the relationship. The proportion of variance explained (R.2) appears alongside every response variable in the model. Goodness-of-fit statistics for each model are shown in the lower right corner (df, degrees of freedom; AIC, Akaike information criterion). * = p < 0.05, ** = p < 0.01, *** = p < 0.001

sec.title: C. filiformis invasion accelerated litter mass loss and element release
sec.p: The invasion of C. filiformis accelerated the mass loss of litter decomposition (Fig. 1). The mass of litter in severe invasive plots was significantly lower than that in uninvaded and mildly invasive plots after three months of litter decomposition. After nine months of litter decomposition, the litter mass in the mildly and severely invasive plots was significantly lower than that in uninvaded plots (Fig. S2). Moreover, the invasion of C. filiformis also accelerated the nutrient release of litter, especially N (Fig. 1 & Fig. 2), which could be related to the invasive plant, C. filiformis, providing high-quality litter into the soil. Characterized by high N content, low C/N and L/N, high-quality litter usually decomposed faster than low-quality litter [10]. Our results showed that the mixed litter samples did have higher N content, but low C/N and L/N than native species litter samples (Fig. 2), which supported the previous perspectives. The invasion of C. filiformis improved the litter quality of native communities. The high decomposition rate of mixed litter was an important reason for the difference in mass loss between uninvaded and invaded plots.

However, C. filiformis invasion could not make all elements decomposing quickly, such as litter carbon (Fig. 2). The early eluviation of litter decomposition made the soluble litter substrates decomposing rapidly, including carbon and other organic matter [34]. The decomposition of LC within the first 3 months of decomposition mainly led to mass loss of litter. After that, the soluble litter substrates decreased, and other substrates had poor decomposability [39]. Our results also showed that the LC content increased at the 3rd and 6 th month of decomposition compared to that of undecomposed litter (Fig. 2). Some studies indicated that the C release of nitrogen-rich leaves was slow after long-time decomposition [30]. Surprisingly, soil C, N, and P content were significantly increasing in the wet season with the invasion of C. filiformis, but not in the dry season (Fig. S3). The invasion of C. filiformis resulted in host plants shedding a large number of leaves underground [25], inputting nutrients into the soil. However, the C/N was significantly higher in the C. filiformis invasive plots than that in uninvaded plots after six months of litter decomposition (Fig. 2), suggesting that the increase of soil nutrients under the invasion of C. filiformis might be at the expense of above-ground biomass loss, and the mixed litter with C. filiformis released a lot of nutrients in a short period of time, rather than a stable long-term release.

sec.title: Enzyme activities were affected by both soil properties and C. filiformis invasion
sec.p: The invasion of C. filiformis delayed the peaking time of enzymes associated with the transformation of litter carbon, nitrogen, and phosphorus during litter decomposition, especially in severe invasive plots (Fig. 3). In severe invasive plots, mixed litter with C. filiformis affected the BG, NAG and ALP activities, which were all peaked at 9 th month of litter decomposition. Besides, the severe invasion of C. filiformis destroyed the host plant canopy, causing a large number of leaves to fall off or even die, resulting in changes in light and temperature understory and biomass loss of aboveground plant communities [25]. Changes of habitat characteristics understory significantly affected soil microbial communities, thereby altering extracellular enzyme activity [22]. The activities of BG and NAG peaked at the 3rd and 6 th month of litter decomposition in uninvaded plots, while those were the highest at the 9 th month of litter decomposition in the severely invaded plots, suggesting the release of LC and LP was significantly delayed by severe C. filiformis invasion.

Except decomposition time and C. filiformis invasive degrees, the activities of different enzymes were also affected by soil properties differently (Fig. 4& 5). The soil pH was significantly positive with BG and NAG, and lower in uninvaded vegetation than in invaded vegetation. The previous studies showed that the soil pH decreased, reducing the BG activity [15]. Soil P supply regulated litter decomposition and soil organic C dynamics. Low soil P supply limited soil microbial activity, slowing litter decomposition [19]. By contrast, high AP had negative effects on BG and NAG activity. Our previous studies had already illustrated that the soil P and AP were significantly higher in native vegetation than those affected by weeds or invasive plants [7, 21]. Although there was no observed correlation between soil C and N contents and the enzyme activities involved in the transformation of LC and LN (Fig. 4), the contents of LC and LN were significantly different under invasive degrees (Fig. 2). This phenomenon might be explained by a long-term study that the release rate of LN was mainly determined by the initial N content of litters and the residual amount of litters [29]. ALP activity was high and only affected by decomposition time, explaining that the LP was stable during litter decomposition. Besides, the soil’s high phosphorus content in the coral island might also be one of the reasons for the high enzyme activity [20].

Unlike the BG and NAG, the activities of PPO and POD had a positive correlation with AP but a negative correlation with pH (Fig. 4). The POD activity was identified as a key defensive mechanism in mitigating reactive oxygen species accumulation in plant tissues induced by environmental stresses [13]. A previous study also indicated that the increment in the activities of POD and PPO enzymes was a defensive mechanism for microorganisms [31]. The soil salinity of tropical coral islands might be the main source of stress. Our results showed that the activities of PPO and POD were higher in invaded plots that in uninvaded plots in all decomposition periods, demonstrating that the invasion of C. filiformis significantly changed the functions and structure of microorganisms. POD activity was significantly higher at the 9 th month of litter decomposition in the invaded plots than that in the uninvaded plots, indicating that the mixing of C. filiformis litter prolonged the stress time. The C. filiformis litter might have allelopathic effects, which can significantly change the litter decay dynamics [4]. The POD activity was affected by most of the environmental factors except soil C and P (Fig. 4& 5). Soil salinity increased significantly under the invasion of C. filiformis and promoted POD activity (Fig. 4 & S2), indicating that the invasion of C. filiformis had a stress effect on the microbial community. We consider that our results may reflect that the high-quality litter of C. filiformis accelerated litter decomposition but also intensified environmental stress, which negatively affected the “plant-soil feedback”.

sec.title: The invasion of C. filiformis regulated the decomposition of litter by affecting enzyme activity and litter quality
sec.p: The decomposition of litter was affected by litter quality, invasive degrees, and decomposition time directly (Fig. 5). Under the invasion of C. filiformis, the high nitrogen content of C. filiformis litter increased the litter quality, accelerating the mass loss of litter (Fig. 2). Generally, litter with high N content decomposed faster than native plant litter [1]. The enzyme activities positively affected the residuals of nutrient concentration in the litter, meanwhile, they were also affected by the invasion of C. filiformis, soil properties and decomposition time. The enzymes were important substances secreted by microorganisms that directly participate in litter decomposition, and their activity was significantly influenced by microbial communities [17]. Our previous study demonstrated that the invasion of C. filiformis changed the characteristics of microorganisms, which was significantly different from the characteristics of microorganisms in the native community [7]. With the changes in microbial characteristics, enzyme activity also underwent significant changes at different degrees of C. filiformis invasion, which might have led to a slowdown in LC decomposition. Many invasive plants accelerated the decomposition rate of litter in invaded ecosystems, which increased the nitrogen content of plants [32]. The increase in plant nitrogen content would further increase the nitrogen content of litter in the ecosystem, thereby accelerating the decomposition of litter and nutrient release in the invaded area. Our previous studies showed that the soil organic carbon content decreased with C. filiformis invasion [7, 20], indicating that C. filiformis promoted soil nitrogen turnover by facilitating mixed litter decomposition, thereby creating a positive feedback to enhance its invasion, which is detrimental to native plant communities and nutrient cycling on coral islands.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In summary, the invasion of C. filiformis and soil properties co-regulated the decomposition of litter, and the invasion of C. filiformis had significant accelerating effects after six months of litter decomposition. The invasion of C. filiformis accelerated the release of N by improving litter quality and accelerated the lignin decomposition by increasing PPO activity but delayed the release of C by decreasing BG activity. The high soil available phosphorus content was negative to litter decomposition in the uninvaded forest community, and the invasion of C. filiformis alleviated these negative effects and promoted litter nutrient release. However, the promotion of litter nutrient release came at the expense of aboveground vegetation biomass loss, creating a"positive feedback"effect that facilitated the invasion of C. filiformis, exacerbating the impact of C. filiformis invasion on the native vegetation of tropical coral islands.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: We thank Yuanhao Cheng, Chengzhi Yuan, Chunqing Long and Kai Ning for assistance with field work and plant species identification, and Xianzhen Luo for helpful comments on the manuscript, and Bangyu Chen for the formal identification of the plant material used in our study. Thanks to the anonymous editor for very constructive comments for this manuscript. We also thank the colleagues of Hainan University and South China Botanical Garden for assistance with plant trait measurements and data collection.

notes.title: Authors’ contributions
notes.p: QL, YH, and HL conceived and designed the study. YH and YC performed most of the experiments. QL, YH, HR and HL wrote and revised the manuscript. KL, SJ, and QZ assisted with data acquisition. QL and YH assisted with data analysis. HR and SJ provided the resources.

notes.title: Funding
notes.p: This study was supported by the the National Key R&D Program of China (Key Special Project for Marine Environmental Security and Sustainable Development of Coral Reefs 2021–400), Scientific Research Foundation of Hainan University (XJ2500000632), Hainan Provincial Natural Science Foundation of China (425QN238), NSFC for Young Scholars (32101369), China Postdoctoral Science Foundation (2021M703261) and the Youth Innovation Promotion Association CAS (2019340).

notes.p: The datasets used and/or analysed during the current study are available from the corresponding author on reasonable request.
